comments.commentBody: Dr. L, It's not being hung, drawn and quartered but being told your previously legal and expensively registered property is no longer legal is confiscation. I don't know what hobby you enjoy but imagine if it was highly regulated and expensive as gun ownership is in New York City. Imagine that each item of your equipment had to be registered at a cost of $140 per item. Imagine that you get a letter from the police that their records indicate you are in possession of an item that was legal when you bought and registered it but is now illegal because of a new law. You have the option of immediately and permanently getting it out of the city with documented proof, immediately turning it over to the police if you can't get it out of the city immediately, turn it in to the cops while you figure out how to remove or sell it or document destruction or permanent alteration by a licensed professional. Are you OK with that? As far as what my Marlin 39A is worth, you display the ignorance most non-gun owners have about firearms. A new 39A costs $650. Depending on age and condition used ones sell for $400-$700 or higher. I paid $350 for my 1970s 39A three years ago. I couldn't replace it with a similar rifle in New York City because all .22 lever action rifles hold more than 5 rounds. NYC outlawed them all including Annie Oakley's favorite. Little did she know she was shooting an assault weapon. I love NY but hate its laws which is why I am moving to PA where gun laws still make sense.

Gentlemen, gentlemen..touche...some good dark humor retorts..

Eric..long shot Lew, the "other" steverino from Seattle.....

Geez..am I agreeing with Eric and QP...correct posts???

What hath God wrought?? Am I turning into a gunnie?

Forbid it almighty god....give me wine and a lower gun death total in America or give me death!!!

PS.. I prefer the lower gun deaths total hands down...say 4k per year in line with our peer countries...

That would make me happy...

"Honest John" you somewhat correctly point out that total auto deaths/injuries in this country outnumber total/death injuries due to guns...

What you don't point out is the the auto number is in line with our peer countries...the gun number is light yrs worse...

"Honest John"...if our gun total matched our peer auto total there would be no need for this blog.

I cannot make it any simpler than that...

HDNY..the last sentence of your post shows some promise in my humble opinion ...your initial post was foaming and the first paragraph of your retort was "rambling"..It aroused the flames of Eric, iggy, QP and da boys...

Your last paragraph was a "poor mans" Lincoln paragraph..

Gunnies...Listen up!!! listen to HDNY poorly written last paragraph..

PS..HDNY...when am I gonna get some classic humorous lines like suckling on the NRA teat from you?

Eric...that was a good dark humor post...remember what johnny Carson said about voters in Chicago vs a third world country..

In a third world country it you vote you are dead...in chicago if you are dead you vote....

geez..this was a tough one...long shot lew vs eric...

I have to give a tko to Eric...not that he was right..but that he was terse...

I suspect that Eric enrolled in the summer or spring session of the Beatty Eye School of terse retorts...

Congrats Eric...
Just so there's no confusion among the people of New Hampshire, remember: It's not about you; it's about him. Or, as he might put it, "Me, me, me."

You are incorrect on all counts.  First, Russia will not stop with Crimea or Ukraine.  Next are the Baltics, Moldova, Poland, Romania and on and on it goes.  We are either going to stop them now, or we will stop them later at greater cost.  You are also wrong that there is nothing we can do.  Right now, Russia is alone, and facing not only all the countries it fought in the Second World War, but all the countries that were on its side in the Second World War.  Allied air forces can take out Russia's Air Force and its best troops in a matter of days, leaving a deteriorated army of demoralized, poorly trained conscripts.  When the Russian people understand the peril Putin has placed their country in, he will be finished.  Then Russia can rejoin the community of nations as a free and democratic state.  My prediction is this ultimately ends very badly for Russia in a very ugly defeat.  It make take some time, but all despots end up the same; like Hitler in the bunker, Hussein in the spider hole, and Gaddafi in the sewer pipe.
Obviously one can preclude a great deal of very stupid irrevocable options by avoiding guns.
Eric..congrats..that was really a terse, well written post...do I sense a modicum of insight here?...fut. post was a left wing rambling post...

Andrea...my favorite comic poster...I expected a little more from you..

Steverino...my favorite extreme left wing poster...it was a good, terse but misguided left wing retort...
great terse retorts..charlie and eric....classic examples of very special Americans suffering from our cultural gun sickness....

Correction...hh and Eric..

Our cultural gun sickness is doing the 33,000 gun killings a year...

In my opinion..a very interesting exchange...

1-Kevin...brought up the issue of car safety...he correctly pointed out that it has been addressed re comparisons to our peer countries re guns.

2-Ronald correctly pointed this out and received a plug from Jen.

3-CR..in her attempt for insight...instead showed her need for enrollment in the Beatty Eye School of terse retorts...CR....the summer session is filling up...
Exactly Jazzbo...very melodic imitation of slaves hoping for emancipation circa 1860....in relation to our cultural gun sickness....not ownership of guns...

Exactly Common Sense...an important post....extreme left wing posters can be just as wrong as extreme right wing posters re our cultural gun sickness..

Bloomberg in his horror re our cultural gun sickness..(He was front and center, explaining to the relatives of 365 dead citizens what happened)

Resorted to extreme measure...ie stop and frisk every person or color...

This is just as wrong as the right wing fanatics who say everybody should have a gun..

Remember in our great country..the extremes will always lose....moderation and advancement in society will always win...
Er, Steve, Soldiers don't get to take their automatic weapons home. The loss of a weapon even in combat is cause for an investigation.

To sum up various comments, plus my own thoughts, r, the rate of return, is not some fixed, abstract value, uniform across an entire economy. Network effects, cronyism, monopoly, regulatory capture, and outright criminal behavior create pockets of high return for certain individuals. Average r is almost irrelevant for aggressive wealthy people.

I'd hazard that Picketty is underestimating internal political (depression backlash/New Deal) and external (WW2, resource availability) forces. The Professor's first question is the key.

"Carmelo needs to be a better passer." So Jackson needs to find
a floor general, i.e. Rondo, and shift Carmelo to loose forward.
Then buy kids like Olnyk.

Or, trade Carmelo for draft picks and go buy some first and second
year NBA talent where available. Get Dolen to open a bait shop
somewhere and become a Zen Bass Pro.
You are anthropomorphizing an object. Something that a 9 year-old girl is smart enough to know not to do.

Hey Poppop,

We agree on a lot. I disagree with you on this one. But I suspect Most of the blog is with you on it, pro and anti gunnies alike. Pro gunnies, because many of them support stricter sentencing in general. Anti gunnies, because they tend to think of all gun folks as criminals, and are always hot to find reasons to throw them in jail.

Judging from the responses to the guest opinion piece, I doubt that most NYT readers, or even the Times itself, disagree with you on this one. I was glad that Maya Schenwan voiced some of my own concerns though. A lonely camp at times.

Cheers.

@poppop --

"The New York Times wants to let armed criminals out of jail"

Wow! I can hardly wait to hear Glen Beck riff on that whopper!

Your melodramatic and misleading statement will no doubt fire up the unthinking on both sides of the gun rights/gun control issue. But is it true?

NO!

If you can't tell the difference between an opinion piece with a personal byline and and editorial stating the position of the NYTimes itself, how can we have an intelligent conversation?

The main takeaway from this opinion piece is that it is not true that mandatory sentencing for gun violations diminishes gun crimes by putting gun criminals away, and that they also act as deterrence. Studies indicate otherwise.

The author also compares mandatory sentences for drug-related crimes, which have filled our prisons to overflowing. The U.S., to its shame, has the highest documented incarceration rate in the world.

California's 3 strikes law has been an abysmal failure, and since its redaction several years ago, studies indicate that prisoners originally incarcerated for minor drug crimes and released under the changed laws have committed new crimes at a significantly lower rate than other released prisoners.

Whatever your ideas about gun crimes (or drug crimes) the article indicates that mandatory sentence are often unjust and do not lead to the outcomes legislators who draft them think they do.
The US is already the most incarcerated country in the world, thanks in part to its firearms policies.

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/15/opinion/reduce-gun-penalties.html

That's right, The New York Times wants to let armed criminals out of jail. I guess to make room for owners of "assault weapons". I just don't know what to say. How can you people sleep at night?

Ther presence of republicons empowers the crazies. If the repubs dr to 39 in the senate and lose the House we would actually see the country move forward. Until that happens we will continue to see filibuster abuse and the House voting on really important things like .....getting to votes 51-75 on denying Americans health insurance, and other important things like the bill they voted yesterday that would (unconstitutionally) force the president to waste federal law enforcement by busting pot in Colorado.

Paola,

You should check the facts. He was in fact on one of the most centrist senators.

It isn't true, but one could possibly think that. Brown runs with a bad crowd. Do I want to see Mitch McConnell as Senate Majority leader? No. Or Ted Cruz, Rand Paul, Mike Lee as committee chairmen? No.
brown was the most centrist of all Senators in his voting. I thought that was the bipartisenship that some wanted.
